Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | ä¸å…¶è¯´æ˜¯åŸå¸‚è¥é€ æˆ–è€…åŸºåœ°å»ºè®¾ï¼Œæ›´åƒæ˜¯æœ‰é™èµ„æºç®¡ç†æ¸¸æˆï¼Œä¸ç¬¦åˆæˆ‘çš„å…´è¶£

9/10 | The game has amazing medieval vibe, really reminds me of Kingdom Come Deliverance, especially its city-building DLC. I am not a big fan of RTS because they feel very stressful to me - not the case for this game, you can build your city and chill until you are ready for a fight. What made me really fall in love with the game is the attention to details - nothing is made out of thin air. For example, if you want to make some ale you need to plow a field, plant barley, wait for it to grow, harvest, transport it to a malt house, craft malt, transport malt to a brewery, craft some ale and finally distribute through a tavern and you can track EVERY process! Your citizens will actually plow a field, build a tavern and malt house brick by brick, transport barley, malt and ale, and finally visit a tavern for a drink.

[h2][b]What Happened to "Discover the World"[/b][/h2]
[hr][/hr]
There is something wrong with the "Discover the world" game mode that seems to be present ever since the December 14th or 20th 2024 update: In this game mode you must unlock a new country every 7 minutes or you fail. Before one of these last 2 patches to the game the game mode was a lot easier to start and now something feels fundamentally broken, in its current state you seem to 6/10 percent of the time get scenarios where you will lose before unlocking the second country or within the first couple few and this is extremely upsetting because this never use to be a problem prior to one of these updates. It was always a challenge, but a fair and enjoyable one. However, now, it feels nearly impossible to even get started.

Also as I've been playing recently, harsh penalties now seem to more frequently trigger way too early in the game, the events such as needing to sell flight tickets at half cost, or the airplane company going on strike causing parts and planes to be x2 the cost. In fact I played 2 games before written this review where half cost flight tickets came up before being able to purchase the first country :/
These used to appear later when you had more infrastructure to handle them. But now, they hit you in the first few minutes, leaving you with no way to recover.

I bought it anticipating a game akin to Mini Metro or Mini Moterway as I really enjoy those 2 games, and both have nice polish and balance, but this just doesn't have the same level as polish. While I was willing to ignore, or for better terms sort of overlook that before as more of a rough edge, now its just too hard because its not just some strange gameplay issues, its frequently being unable to actually achieve what the game expects, and that's just not fun. 

I hope the developers take a closer look at these updates and restore the balance that made "Discover the World" an enjoyable and rewarding experience, If that happens, I could see myself giving this game a more positive review, although the game still does lack the polish of the other titles I mentioned above, and its gameplay loop becomes stale far too quickly, Scenarios mode is there as well but definitely is not as good at making the game less stale as additional maps, though I understand how that wouldn't be as easy to do in this game vs the game I mentioned. | This game is bad. A very addictive RPG visual novel set in a sci-fi/cyberpunk future.

You play as a sleeper, an emulated consciousness uploaded into a synthetic robotic body. A victim of corporate propaganda, you signed a contract of servitude, selling your real body away for the promise of a life off-world. But after losing faith in this promised future, you escaped with others from your indentured servitude. Being the only one to make it out alive, caught between a stolen past and an uncertain future, you find yourself on a decaying space station where you must evade the hunters after you and survive, all while trying to buy or synthesize the stabilizer you need to postpone your planned obsolescence.

I found the writing excellent and became completely engrossed by the different life stories of the station's inhabitants. It was easy to get attached to the various characters living on the station.
I also really liked the game's characters design, which reminded me of Katsuhiro Otomo's art style.
And the electronic music was a perfect fit for conveying the atmosphere of isolation and desperation on the station in the game's dystopian world.

Gameplaywise, I didnt find the game particularly difficult. After getting the hang of the mechanics, completing tasks and progressing through the game was fairly easy. Failure was ok as the game was quite forgiving. In my single playthrough, I only missed three achievements. The game has many endings, but you can continue playing by pressing [continue] after the end credits. To experience more endings, always choose the option to leave the station first, when given a choice.
It also didnt seem like the type of sleeper you started with really mattered. I finished the game with 4 out of my 5 sleeper skills fully upgraded.

The game's main strength lies in its fantastic writing and storytelling. So, if you enjoy great sci-fi/cyberpunk stories, you should definitely play this. | Impossible vibes. It's like if the comforting isolation of falling asleep to a white noise generator was a RPG. Incredible game and a very cool interpretation of a distant sci-fi/ cyberpunk future. | This game has some of the most beautiful stories and characters I've seen in a video game, or even some novels I've read. Over the years, you just don't find things like this. I'm a war hardened, grown man, and some of the story threads in this cut me deep. Thank you for this experience. | Citizen Sleeper is an OK game. In this glorified VN you play as a rogue "Sleeper" (hey, that's half the name of the game!) a robot with the brain of someone in cryostasis trying to escape the clutches of the evil corporation that employed you. Citizen Sleeper utilizes its cyberpunk influence to make a very compelling college brochure / kinetic novel, but not necessarily an interesting game.
To not be entirely dour on the game I'll conceit, I played the game, I got 3 of the 6 endings, and I only fell asleep twice. The core slash only gameplay mechanic of knowing what your dice rolls will be before you have a skill check is pretty nifty, and lets you choose to prioritize succeeding at the things you want to succeed at and fail at things you don't really care about. The game actually has an interesting cyberpunk setting and world its built, as opposed to the usual "future city but neon and bad" sloppa you usually get. The game can be finished in one or 2 short sittings. The look of the game is fairly iconic and inspired, and while you might not like the vaguely zog adjacent character designs, it is its own style and you're not going to see other games of the similar setting even remotely attempt this ambition, especially with its small 3 man team, even larger in breadth of scope and intention of design, so you have to admire the sheer passion and care involved.
And we've come to the part where I become a big fat meanie, so if you read that and are like "wow, hey wait, [i]I[/i] like words and pictures! I'm going to buy this now!" please, be my guest, its not bad.




[i]However[/i],,,
Citizen sleeper is not a game!!!! It's a VN with extra clicking!!!! The writing is one note, every character speaks in the same voice and I can't tell you anything a character said beyond aphorisms, cliches, occasional vague left footed marxist toe steps, and brief fellations towards the unnamed player character. A former soldier tells you his adopted daughter "saved him, actually", another tells you that you just don't get it do you, and my personal favourite, when you help a bounty hunter kill a man and she pays you, you drop the money on the ground and say "what life is worth this". I promise you, that you can google every cliche movie line and I guarantee its somewhere in this game spoken by the widely diverse cast of characters. That dice thing I talked about earlier becomes negligible past the first or second hour as once you've gained a couple levels, you can acquire the ability to reroll at any point during a turn, even when you only have one die left. Naturally, I abused this to get the main ending i wanted out of the game, because why not. In general though, levelling up trivializes the game, your first level, if you so choose can be spent to negate any weaknesses your character class had, you CAN add plus 2 bonuses to your rolls but by the end i was rolling too many 5's and 6's to even think of that as an investment. There's a skill to regain health and stamina for free, but you get so much money for every little thing you do you have to go OUT OF YOUR WAY TO FAIL AT ANYTHING. The game constantly terges and teases impending doom and choices mattering, however, I realized early on you don't actually have any agency in the solipsistic monologues the characters speak to you, so I said the meanest dialogue option I could, every time, and, every time, they would just ignore me and keep monologuing about the world. Speaking of doom, I'll let you know now, if you run out of health? You get put back to half health at the cost of one of your buffs/debuffs, if you run out of time on your bounty hunter missions? You get the same cutscenes as you would if you were a good boy. You are simply watching the story unfold from the eyes of another, the room starts spinning and I begin experiencing extreme depersonalization, is this how it is in the game? or is this every day for me? Do I truly want the life I lead? Do I have the choice to not want it after all? These are the questions I ask myself as I click through dialogues, rush through sidequests for my favourite characters, then distributing my worst rolls in a pyramidial manner to characters I like slightly less and so on so forth.


In the world of Disco Sleeper, there's a heavy dearth over the whole universe that capitalism has made things as awful as they are, and I don't mind me a good rage against the machine, hey, I rage against the machine myself too sometimes,

[i]However[/i], 
I do have a problem when its so piss easy to progress in whatever way you want it makes the evil society look ideal. Like in the world of citizen sleeper, you save every minute so you can walk away whenever you want, and there's no consequences for doing absolutely nothing to help yourself. And even moreso everyone is so nice to eachother there's no danger in the world at all. People in mortal bitter rivalries talk out their problems, people steal and get stolen from with no desire for reprisal. The one character that does anything remotely morally questionable immediately renounces her 'evil' (she was in the right btw) ways and decides to abandon her current life for that similar to one of a nun. So its not just the player that all this is just insanely easy for. This world is awesome to live in, this awful world is better to live in than my actual real awful world. If this is the world that the evil capitalists built for the people of Erlin's Eye, sign me up. Sign me up for 2 even, so I can wreck one.

And despite all this, the game was alright. There IS an interesting world and ideas behind all the genera and eye-rolling, I'd buy it on a sale or something if you're willing to live with the big howevers mentioned above.

If you're looking for a similar idea of what you're getting into I'd liken this game to Va1ha11a cyberpunk bartending, where there's an incredibly shallow gameplay mechanic and an incredibly shallow story and they're both smushed together so you don't really realize why neither portion are as good or fleshed out as they could be. | I enjoyed this one quite a bit. More of a visual novel than a typical game.

Pretty good writing but not mind-blowing. The gameplay mechanics are under-developed, especially towards the end they become a bit of a chore. 

But! The story, characters and situations as a whole make up for the flaws. This a very immersive and emotional experience, it really manages to transport you into its world. So overall it's worthwhile.

I'm digging this game. Only two matches in on Ranked. Here's my perspective:
- I'm not a Dune series / movies fan
- Very good tutorial; I also watched someone explain the physical board game to get more of the references
- Match making system is every 30 minutes, they start matches of 3-4 players.
- Matches last about 2.5 hours. I felt a bit drained after my first match, mostly because of the length. On the one side I felt this was way too long, but there were some turns where I wish I had more time to execute my actions, so I guess it's just right really.
- Feels like development on this game is thoughtful and intentional, and the UI is easy to navigate. There's just something so fun about aggressively bullying a demonic archfiend of hell into giving you their pocket money. 

I have experienced quite a few UI bugs while playing, such as being unable to dismiss notifications and having to reload into the game because it's blocking options you need, and I frequently experience a lot of lag when dragging tribute tokens. It's nothing game breaking, my friends haven't experienced it, and I love this game otherwise, but it's only fair to mention.

Otherwise, I personally love the art (even the archfiends), the music and the gameplay. The start can feel frustrating when you're stuck on two order slots, but strategising to find how to increase them as quickly as you can while also defending yourself and harassing others is one of the most satisfying parts of the game for me (aside from spamming demands as Andromalius so you can duel praetors). Even something as small as the order in which you take actions can make or break the game, and there's a lot of depth in terms of the options you have available to you when you explore the game.

I also highly recommend giving the chronicles a go, I love the unique dialogue you can receive while playing them. It really adds to the archfiends' characterisation and gives some extra little tidbits of lore. | Great strategy game that can be played asynchronously.
Give yourself and your opponents sleepless nights and learn to scheme! | Interesting take on the 4X format, game slaps in multiplayer with friends, its surprisingly fun where you would expect it to be frustrating. | As others have said, approach this more as a board game than as a Civ game: for most of the game, you're only getting 2-3 actions per turn, and victory (usually) comes down to counting points. Games move quickly and force you to prioritize what you do each turn: move units, collect resources, conduct diplomacy, purchase new units or upgrades, etc. It's a pleasant 2-3 hour tactical diversion. | Amazing game, wonderful to have a few games going which I can play before I go to work!

It's a Twilight Imperium 4th edition knockoff. Don't get me wrong, great idea, TI4 is a fantastic game and Stellaris Nexus  (because that's what it was sold as all through EA and it changed less than a month before release) does a decent job of it. Sadly, whatever support it was  going to get was probably gutted when Paradox rug pulled the Stellaris theme from it, changed the name to that of a phone, pushed 1.0 release, and dropped it like a rock. It's highly doubtful it'll receive any additional updates or playable races, the potential for multiplayer outside known friend groups is slightly more lively than a cactus shop in the Sonora, and there are still some rather glaring bugs that will probably never be fixed. It's depressing really, you can tell the devs were really excited until they put out a completely bland corporate buzzword filled post about the name changing, EA ending, and a launch without any fanfare. Old World (OW) is brilliant in its design and the experience it creates. OW is the most interesting, if not the best, 4x, tactical, turn based strategy currently! Complex, challenging and fun!

(MANY) POSITIVES
1 AN AMAZING PACE: OW has a brilliant mechanic of Orders that limits how much you can do in a turn. Everything, but production in cities, costs Orders: moving and using workers, scouts, army, attacking, council tasks, interactions with courtiers and nations. Each turn you think, prioritize and make choices. 
This way everything in OW feels earned. Because of the Orders limitation even in the late game a war can be exhausting for your empire. Moving many army units can deplete your Orders pool, not leaving any for workers, heir education, or scouts. Of course things get easier with time, but still you can find yourself vulnerable. One of the rare strategy games where the late game is cool!

2 CLEVER SYNERGY OF THE GAME'S SYSTEMS
In OW everything relates in a deep, satisfying way. Opinions of you impact how well armies fight, productivity of your cities, courtiers interactions with you. Resources and Buildings have efficiency combinations. All systems of OW interact.

3 TACTICAL WARS WITH PROPER AI
OW has competent AI that plays the game properly. It's perhaps a 4x game with one of the better AIs I've played against. In a war it tries to flank you for max damage, shoot from hills for maximum range, use forests to minimize ranged damage etc. War in OW is tactical. Flanking, units adjacency, terrain, and preparation (you can't heal in a neutral land, unless you have certain skills) - it all matters. 

4 DIPLOMACY IS COMPLEX AND CRUCIAL
Diplomacy in OW has two levels: internal and international with Opinions mechanic that synergizes with other systems. 
In OW you don't just establish cities of your civilization. With each new city you choose a renown family to run it (3 families each game out of 4 options; each nation has a different set). They have different bonuses, interactions with terrain, demands and limits to what character can govern their city. This way cities are different to each other. The Families opinion matters. Low Family opinion affects the maintenance of their cities. Armies you produce belong to the families and their combat effectiveness synergizes with your internal diplomacy as well (including General's opinion of you if one is added to an army).
On top of that you also have individual characters (courtiers) with friendships, love affairs, rivalry, assassinations, ambitions (power hungry), or significant public popularity (Rising Stars that can overthrow you). You also have civil wars where you may end up destroying your own city. 
Wars in OW can be intense and can significantly compromise what you can do in a turn. It really pays off to prevent war with a political marriage, even with a tribal leader against the public opinion, than risk invasions on multiple fronts. Besides, happiness in attacked cities tanks down and this can trigger further problems (unhappiness raises city's maintenance and a chance of rebellion). War in OW is a big deal: victories can boost your Legitimacy, but defeats break it. You need alliances and proper diplomacy to secure survival. You invest in building trust (Opinion) for more diplomatic options. 

5 The BARBARIANS, TRIBES AND FIXED CITY SPOTS
Besides different nations OW has Barbarians and 6 different tribes. Tribes may occupy vast or smaller map space with their camps. And the tribes in OW can be devastating. Each camp spawns units every few years and if too many they become raiders, even if you're at peace with them. You can get unexpected mini invasions where they pillage, attack cities and wound/kill workers. So your city placement, armies stationing and natural barriers like mountains play a role. 
There are benefits to defeating tribes and to alliances with them. In OW you have fixed city settlement locations. A few guaranteed ones at the start; more you get from warfare or diplomacy. I think the fixed City Spots improve the game significantly. There's no dumb AI settling a city on your border for irrational tensions. And a wide expansion makes you think and plan how you can secure distant, new cities. 
Overall, the tribes in OW add a lot of tension, threat and historical sensitivity that I really like.

6 ECONOMY WITH THE RIGHT AMOUNT OF RESOURCE TYPES
All resources matter and you can run short of something even in the late game. Access to the best units is not just a matter of tech, but also depends on the level of your culture, a chain of buildings and multiple resources to maintain them.

7 DYNAMIC, MORTAL CHARACTERS
Playing as a mortal ruler, that you develop in stats and traits, is more fun than having one fixed option throughout eras.
I love the Archetypes for Characters, with different layers of bonuses when acting as the Leader, Governor or army Commander. For Instance a Builder Leader can assign multiple workers to a project and they have -1 turn to build improvements and more. 
It's also brilliant that courtiers' stats contribute to the resources pool of your empire. Giving them a job provides a yearly experience, thus upgrades. Using courtiers missions gives them even more experience. This way even having spy agents in foreign empires benefit your resources pool. Its a dynamic system where you want to use courtiers, they change and play an important role. 

8 EVENTS THAT BRING FLAVOR AND VARIETY
OW claims to have over 3 thousand events!!! Some go in chains and develop over time. Some involve historic characters and situations. I love that the OW events pop up with jingle sounds! Big, immersive windows with beautiful art! Love all the art of Wonders especially â€“ they represent so well the grand scale of these projects! My favorite events are when a courtier becomes inspired by my empire's wonder (that they aren't just buildings with buffs) and when a battles winning general becomes a Rising Star and creates a political threat. It's empire AND character building together with storytelling.

9 there is DEPTH, NUANCES, AND HISTORIC SENSITIVITY
So many things in OW make it's "world" alive and interesting beyond the clickfest of developing tiles or attacking.
When your worker is wounded it builds a turn longer. 
When you're allied with a tribe you control their units. And when ravaged by war a Tribe can ask you for refuge, creating slums in your city. 
Scouts in OW can do many things and remain useful. From providing Legitimacy for discovered landmarks, to harvesting resources and spying. With proper tech, a Scout can establish spy network in foreign city. Then your spies can provide you with vision and destabilization options; for instance you can try to trigger rebellions in several cities at once right before you attack. All these in a Civilization like game!!!

I also like that the Tech options are semi-random.

10 ART STYLE, (fantastic) MUSIC, and ATMOSPHERE
Music in the OW is just AWESOME! Sometimes I just keep playing OW because I enjoy its soundtrack so much. 
It's a good looking game that sticks to one period of history but with depth and atmosphere. This way playtime isn't that long, but isn't short either. Due to the Orders mechanic limitations other players turns go fast, so less waiting time.

LAST BUT NOT LEAST
The game has never crashed for me.
I haven't found OW to be overwhelming to learn. It took me around 10 hours to become familiar with all the basics. OW has an excellent in-game encyclopedia.
The game is very customizable. 
The base game of OW has the full, good experience and not hiding crucial features behind paid DLCs. 
OW is first and foremost a great strategy game (with RPG flavor). It has a healthy complexity, depth, historic references, and fulfilling struggle.

NEGATIVES
In spite of symmetrical design, I've got an impression some nations are much better than others. I'm still figuring out if it's inflexibility of my playstyle or design's imbalance. | I am a university professor, game developer, and 4X TBS game fanatic. I played, developed, collaborated on, play tested, analyzed, wrote about, and searched for 4X TBS games most of my life. 
I played thousands of games and tens of thousands of hours of TBS games. I make this post after 300 hours of playing Old World. My estimated level of knowing and understanding Old World and its features: 60%.
Far from being perfect, but my perception is that Old World is currently the second best game out there. (I may be biased to 4X TBS, although I played many other genres).
Old World has the usual big problems with the UI: cumbersome, confusing, slow, buggy. Its AI seems to be somewhat better than the other 4X TBS AIs. As of today, 4X TBS AIs without exception are very poor based on my personal experience with hundreds of these games. 
But Old Worldâ€™s design is one of the best I have seen so far in any 4X TBS game. Finally, I see Order Points that limit the number of actions per turn and limit my movements. I advocated for this for 30 years in 4X TBS development. This game has great feature diversity, depth, and attention to details. Many things can be customized, even the music. I am yet to try the multiplayer. The developers genuinely understand and care about their product which combo is rare to find in the 4X TBS genre. This is not just another dumbed down â€œcloneâ€ of an earlier game that dominates the 4X TBS market today. They still push new patches which is great. This game is similar to Civilization 4, but much better. It also has tactical depth, role playing, and probabilistic planning, and a lot more. Kudos to the developers and I wish they will provide many years of support to fix the bugs, improve the UI, further tune the balance, and strengthen the AI to make the game even better than now.

I've been spending up to 12 hours a day in this game for days now, and it's just stupidly overpowered against the player. Just when you start to get things right, the game sh_its on you. I have a 13900K (Yes, I did the BIOS update to keep it from melting.) with a Lian Li 360 AIO running at full speed 100% of the time, and a total of 7 fans. 32GB of DDR5, and a 2080Super. I watch HWMointor because this game makes my computer a Space Heater. I watch voltages, I watch clock speeds on all cores, and I watch temperatures. No other game does this to my machine.
I don't know how people play this and are OK with it. 
I'll probably uninstall.
Don't buy it. It's not what you think it is.

A more relaxing game and not so funny than Two Point Hospital, this is however a very good simulation. This means that it's a pleasure to watch your minions, i.e. staff and students, going about their business and making you smile from time to time.

There are many courses you can put in your Uni and you must build a lot of rooms to make it functional. I like to build the rooms much more than in TPH because I can put more things in them, not a lot of the same posters.

For those of you not familiar with Two Point Hospital, playing this game is in fact building a University with rooms for classes, dormitories, bathrooms, places to eat and socialize, laboratories. and making sure that you are making money and make all your minions happy and serving the students enough knowledge to graduate with high honors. You can train your teachers and do research to upgrade some of your equipment.
The game is structured in missions and you have objectives to finish them from one to three stars. It's long. I've finished half of the missions in 45 hours. Not including the ones from the DLC, but playing mostly on normal speed, because I really love to watch the simulation. It makes me smile or laugh.

Pros:
- great simulation of an university
- clear and attainable objectives in mission
- relaxing and not at all frustrating (TPH has some annoying grindy moments)
- funny all over the place; the radio is hilarious and some animations too
- it's a pleasure to watch your minions doing their business in your great building af knowledge that you've build with money and sweat
- great music; actually Two Point games are almost the only ones that I play with the sound loud enough to listen what they say

Cons:

This game can be summarized in one word: Unpolished

I really want to love this game however in its current state it really is unloveable. If you plan to buy this just be aware that you'll "only" get a few hundred hours of fun out of this game as opposed to Paradox usual thousand. And this will not change for a long (at the time of writing this, presumably a few years of) time.

Every nation feels and mostly plays the same and its unpolished state applies to both game mechanics AND [nation]flavour.

If you want to know how you'll play 90% of games if you want to do decently well it will look like this: 1. Pick a great power, 2. liberalize, 3. build an economic based on a construction bubble (Iron, steel, tools) and 4. repeat.

Minor nations are even less playable because by the time you fixed your nation the game is already or close to over.

Im gonna list every Problem I have with this game just do demonstrate the unpolished state of the game however be aware this is by far not every problem the game has to offer:

1. The Warfare system is boring, now theres a lot of criticism for the warfare system by the community however this is one of the features that is in my opinion the least in need of fixing. While it is very oversimplified (You basically draw a frontline and then either attack or defend). I think all this game needs are polishing features like frontlines splitting in 2 causing you to have a hole in your line and causing you to be instantly overrun. Military Research actually affecting your units instead of changing your production method (the Ultra Historical mods fix this). And adding a stockpile for equipment so your military factories stay productive in peace time. Plus making your attack orders actually be followed would go a long way.

2. The game runs super slow by the time you reach 1890 [depending on your PC, +/- ~10 years]. This is especially annoying because it means you get cut off from a lot of cool action. It essentially means you'll rarely see your fruits of labor pay off. Want to play Germany and establish colonies? By the time you've unified Germany and have done all the important other things the game is already slowing down. Want to play as a socialist country? By the time you're ready to become socialist your game is so slow that waiting for laws to pass is no longer fun but just annoying. Want to be Japan? By the time you implemented the right laws the game is too slow to start Japans historic rapid industrialization. Want to play as an American trade empire? By the time you unified America you'll at best have time to get the South Americas into your sphere of influence.

3. The economy system sucks. Want to build an economy as any Great power? Heres how, 1. build iron/coal mines and logging camps, make tools, repeat. 2. Unlock Steel, steel needs iron and coal, iron needs tools, make more tools using steel. 3. Unlock Dynamite, make sulfur mine, make fertilizer factory. Dynamite needs fertilizers which you make with sulfur, then you use the dynamite production method to get more resources out of mines.... resources like sulfur. And that's basically it, now go Laisez Fairre so your capitalists invest in some other stuff so you can larp the semblance of a diverse economy.

3b. Trading sucks. Hoi4 has a more interesting trade mechanic/balance then this game. Every game devolves into an Autarky Simulator. Don't have enough of something? What can you do? You have to build it yourself. Basically no shortage except engines and other rare goods can be fixed using trade. Want to larp an imperialist power that dumps massive amounts of cheap goods into a country causing local competitors to go bankrupt forcing the country to economically rely on you? Tough luck, you cant.[This is a game about colonialism and trading by the way]

4. The politics of this game are super boring and lame, if you want to be decently successful you have 2 options: Capitalist Liberalism to focus on a game with a lot of GDP or Communism to see that standard of living go up. There is no incentive to play anything else. Monarchism and other Authoritarian ways to play only compensate you with "Authority" which are points you can use to implement decree's that buff you in a selected state in a bunch of different ways however quite frankly, its useless. And while its obvious that playing as a Theocratic Ethnostate will have little benefits, there is absolutely no reason other then larp to pick them.  Theres no specific unique buff, no odd situational event, nothing. They could have went with something like Monarchies uniting the populace causing less Radicals from political movements or Ethnostates/Theocracies giving less radicals from Standard of Living for the Primary culture but more for oppressed cultures but they chose nothing and hence you are always forced to pick the same old boring policies.

5. The game lacks utter immersion. Despite this game being set in unarguably one of the most important and most rapid changing times of humanity you, the player, feel nothing about it. Are you an industrial great power? Are you a small, non industrial tribe? Are you an oppressed puppet/colony? It "feels" the same. The game lacks utter immersion, while even hoi4 tries to immerse you in its setting with news events like the olympic games, the Hindenburg, etc. no such thing is going on in vicky, add this with the already distant experience from the Global Strategy approach and you're in for a dissapointment. Very very rarely do you feel like you're in these turbulent times. Events that are supposed to immerse you rarely work to do that. The only events that do make me feel immersed are that of nihilism, positivism and communism. However 2 of these rarely fire. And it is just as bad for nation specific immersion. As Prussia/Germany, you'll never feel like you're uniting people that want to be united, you just start 3 wars, get an event and annex lands. Or as Japan, you do not get experiences that make you feel like your world was basically turned upside down when the Europeans [yes Europeans because America will not even reach you] open up your country. There is a massive missed chance of adding visual novel'esque events [or news events like hoi4 does] that immerse you. Imagine how great it would be, you play as Japan and suddenly you're forced to open up. And while you change your laws you keep getting pop ups about people/interest groups describing their perspective of a changing Japan. You could see how displeased the Samurai's are getting with each event, how they feel about losing their privileges while for the Peasantry you feel their sweeping optimism as  they went from the bottom of the hierarchy to a respected group. Ultimately this is a huge missed potential that is also surprisingly not alot talked about in the community.

heres a lot more to say and criticize but I've reached my steam word limit... yeah that one sentence sums up the vicky 3 experience.

All in all this game just quite frankly sucks due to a lack of polish. Usually mod's fix this in other games but it is to severe in this game to fix. You need different major mods for every single aspect. I personally run the entire 5 or so Ultra Historical mods to fix research, combat and the lack of a historical ai. The better politics mod to make politics slightly less repetitive (they still are). Various Quality of life UI mods, performance improving mods, Event and Flavour mods. And always 1 Flavour mod for the nation Im planning to play.

And this won't be fixed within one update or a dlc, this will take a lot which is why I don't recommend it. If they keep the progress up, in 2 years I'd say this game enters a "releasable bare bones" state. As it is, you get a few hundred hours out of playing different nations and getting familiar with the game mechanics until you realize its all the same.

The game is that perfect brain teaser in a visually pleasing package.. you look at a new shape and freak out at all the steps involved, then you design a factory that ends up being way more compact and efficient than you ever thought *feels good* and once that's delivered, you get introduced to the next layer of complexity.

Herkese baÅŸlangÄ±Ã§ta zor geliyor sÃ¼reÃ§ten keyif alÄ±n. son olarak deniz Ã§Ä±karmalarÄ±na ve lojistik gÃ¼cÃ¼nÃ¼ze dikkat edin. | In many war games it feels like you can simply roll up on someone/country and begin fighting. Paradox Interactive in all their games, but especially this one, have a 'casus belli'/war goal rule where it not only delays wars so you can set the pace of combat but stop other AI from immediately destroying you. Along with the choice (mostly just the major countries) to rewrite history and can actually see how different the war would've been. So far my favorite alt history choice has been bringing back Napoleon for France and rebuilding the French Empire, as well as the option to oppose Hitler giving the chance for Germany to be anything but fascist.
Overall, if you enjoy history and have the patience to sit though a game as you stumble around to figure out every detail then definitely look into this one. Even myself, with 215 hrs, have yet to master the game but it's still enjoyable by myself or with friends.

It combines a campaign map with turn based battles. You can create your own civilization with its ruler and heroes, and play as the fantasy (or steam-punk) civilization you always wanted.

But I have some bigger issues with this game:

First off, since the last big update, the game has a tendency to crash on the campaign map. Which is really annoying, but dealbreaker for me is, that it also corrupts saves, so you cannot continue where it crashed. Especially annoying when you just fought a big battle and then lose all your progress.

Second is, that yes - you can create different civs - but in the end, they all play very similar. You always want to rush your city cap and just build as many armies as possible. Build wide, claim as much territory as possible. That's the strategy. The only difference is how your units look and what tomes you unlock. To be fair, some of the final tomes are very unique, but it takes a very long time till you get there and most of the game is already over by that point.

Third, the campaign map itself. You notice it is randomly generated. It's a combination of biomes with some features in it and some randomly placed ancient wonders. Every map looks similar. Sometimes it has more forest and sometimes more sand, but in the end, there are no "unique" landmarks or sights. After a few games, you have seen everything. Which would be okay, but one of the key points of this game is to go out and explore the map... which is just not interesting.

A monumental game in my gaming career, Half-Life 2 was that defining experience that made me realise I was in for something next level. For the first time i picked it up on The Orange Box in 2008, and from the moment I booted it up, I knew I was in for a wild ride. It wasnâ€™t just a gameâ€”it was an event. The environments were absolutely massive, the atmosphere was unreal, and the soundtrack? Edgy as hell. Every moment felt like a cinematic journey.

In Half-Life 2, you play as Gordon Freeman, arguably one of the most reluctant action heroes in gaming. You awaken from stasis, burdened with the trauma of the previous game, and are immediately thrust into action as the figurehead of an uprising. This isnâ€™t a simple revolutionâ€”itâ€™s a battle against a multiversal alien threat, shrouded in dystopian themes and orchestrated by secretive organizations manipulating events behind the scenes.

Set in a world dominated by the Combine, an alien regime that combines interdimensional authoritarianism with advanced technology, you must navigate a planet under their control. Armed with little more than a crowbar and your signature nonverbalism, Gordon becomes the key figure in the resistance. As you progress, you'll engage in intense combat, solve puzzles, explore diverse environments, and uncover the unsettling truth that nothing in this world is as it seems.

And letâ€™s talk about The G-Manâ€”a mysterious, interdimensional CIA glowman who pops up like a bad dream and probably controls the entire charade like a cosmic puppeteer. Is he good? Is he bad? Is he just playing the long game? Who knows, but heâ€™s definitely got his hand in everything, watching Gordon like a hawk, pulling strings like an invisible god. 

Youâ€™d think itâ€™s just a sci-fi conspiracy, but after a while, you start questioning if anyone really knows what the hell is going on. Does G-Man even have a purpose, or is he just a cosmic observer who gets his kicks out of watching a man with a crowbar take on the end of the world?

The gameâ€™s narrative feels like a giant puzzle, and each step forward opens up even more questions, all while youâ€™re tearing through enemy lines, trying to get answers. And the best part? Itâ€™s not all about combatâ€”there are puzzles to solve, mysteries to uncover, and a sense of isolation that keeps you on edge, constantly wondering who or what will show up next. The pacing is incredible, making you feel like youâ€™re a tiny piece of something far larger, with consequences that span across dimensions.

ä¸ºä»€ä¹ˆè¿™ä¸ªæ»‘æ¢¯ä¸èƒ½ä¸Šå»ï¼Œè¿™ä¸ªè··è··æ¿æ˜¯å¯ä»¥ç©çš„ï¼ŒåŸæ¥è¿™é‡Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å°å·§æ€ï¼Œè¿™é‡Œçš„ç”µçº¿æ˜¯è§†è§‰å¼•å¯¼ç‰©ï¼Œæ€æ ·ä¿æŒä¸€ä¸ªä¼‘é—²å’Œç´§å¼ çš„å¹³è¡¡ï¼Œèƒ½åœ¨æ¸¸æˆé‡Œäº²è‡ªä¸Šæ‰‹è·Ÿçœ‹GDCæˆ–è€…å·¥å…·ç®±æ˜¯å®Œå…¨ä¸ä¸€æ ·çš„ä½“éªŒï¼Œæˆ‘ä¼šè´ªå©ªåœ°å¸Œæœ›æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæˆ‘å–œæ¬¢çš„æ¸¸æˆéƒ½æ·»åŠ å¼€å‘è€…è¯„è®ºã€‚ | "Half-Life 2" is one of the most influential and groundbreaking first-person shooters ever made. Released in 2004 by Valve, it redefined what players could expect from a video game in terms of both storytelling and gameplay. The gameâ€™s narrative is immersive, unfolding without traditional cutscenes, which allows the player to feel like they are truly part of the story. The protagonist, Gordon Freeman, is a silent hero who navigates through a dystopian world filled with alien invaders and oppressive human forces. This unique approach to storytelling pulls the player into the gameâ€™s world, making every action feel meaningful.

The physics engine in "Half-Life 2" was revolutionary for its time. The way objects interact with the environment feels natural and intuitive, and it became a major part of the gameplay. From solving puzzles using physics to creatively using the environment as a weapon, it was an innovation that influenced many games that followed. The gravity gun, which allows players to manipulate objects in real-time, is still one of the most memorable and fun weapons in gaming history.

The level design in "Half-Life 2" is another standout feature. The game introduces players to varied environments, from the dark, industrial city of City 17 to the eerie, remote marshlands. Each location feels carefully crafted, with attention to detail that makes the world feel alive. The pacing is also masterful, alternating between moments of intense combat and slower, atmospheric sequences that allow the player to soak in the environment and story.

The AI in "Half-Life 2" was also ahead of its time. Enemies behave intelligently, using cover, working together, and reacting to the playerâ€™s actions in a way that makes combat more dynamic and challenging. The enemy variety, from the terrifying Combine soldiers to the creepy headcrabs, keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The interactions with NPCs and the world around you help build a sense of tension and immersion, keeping you on edge throughout the experience.

The game's soundtrack, composed by Kelly Bailey, perfectly complements the atmosphere, using subtle but effective music to enhance both the action and the quieter moments. The sound design is top-notch, with ambient sounds adding to the immersion, whether you're in a busy city street or exploring a deserted warehouse.

Ultimately, "Half-Life 2" is a masterpiece that still holds up to this day. Its innovative gameplay, storytelling, and technical achievements make it a game that set a new standard for the industry. Itâ€™s a game thatâ€™s not just fun to play, but one thatâ€™s easy to appreciate for the way it shaped the future of video games. Even though itâ€™s been years since its release, "Half-Life 2" remains a classic that continues to inspire both players and developers alike.

 | game is fire but whoever designed the puzzles and the vehicle section i hope you never work in games again. also barney thick as hell | Half-Life 2 is quite a game and i don't know what to say about it other than its a personal favourite. I think its one of my favourite of the Half-Life games just for all the upgrades it brings. The physics and all the new graphics and visuals. Its truly a great leap in the series and i love how far the story has come and how everything was ended nicely.

The story was more developed and the characters had more dialogue with each other and you saw some past characters return quite nicely. The aliens returned in this sequel to the first Half-Life and once again you had to beat them back. You are led through multiple chapters in the game defeating enemies and playing through some thought provoking puzzles as per the series standard.

One thing i miss is that the game ended on an unfortunate cliff hanger and so far there seems to be no sign of a sequel at all. The story needs finishing and has spent way to long without any news at all about its future and will be in limbo for some time.

The game without a doubt in my mind is the best in the series and one of my favourites. Its a easy game to recommend anyone try out and play in the future.

Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a multiplayer first-person shooter developed by Valve. It is a remake of the classic Half-Life deathmatch mode, utilizing the Source engine. The game combines the fast-paced action of traditional deathmatch with updated graphics and more fluid movement mechanics. While it successfully brings new life to the original concept, some mechanical issues and a niche player base prevent it from being as popular as its predecessors.

What Works Well?
ğŸ® Classic Deathmatch Gameplay
The core of Half-Life: Deathmatch is its tight, fast-paced combat. It stays true to the original deathmatch mode, offering classic weapons, high-speed action, and simple, enjoyable mechanics. The formula remains as fun today as it was when first introduced.

ğŸŒ† Updated Graphics with Source Engine
The move to the Source engine has significantly improved the visuals compared to the original. The lighting, textures, and models are much sharper, breathing new life into the iconic Half-Life universe. The environments feel more immersive, and physics interactions are more dynamic.

ğŸ”« Familiar Weapon Set
Players have access to a variety of classic weapons from the Half-Life series, including the crowbar, shotgun, and crossbow, all of which perform as expected. Each weapon has its own strategic value, and they all function well within the confines of the deathmatch setting.

ğŸ› ï¸ Modding Support and Custom Servers
As with other Source engine games, Deathmatch: Source allows for a robust modding community. Players can easily find custom servers and user-created content, from new maps to modified gameplay modes, keeping the experience fresh.

What Could Be Better?
âŒ Limited Popularity and Player Base
Despite its solid foundation, Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source suffers from a relatively small player base. As newer games in the genre continue to dominate, it can be difficult to find active matches, especially in more niche servers.

âŒ Physics Can Feel Clunky
While the Source engine improved many aspects of the game, some of the physicsâ€”especially in terms of movementâ€”can feel a little awkward compared to modern shooters. The transition to 3D space feels a bit more restrictive than anticipated, particularly when compared to the fluidity of more modern games.

âŒ No Significant Gameplay Innovation
While the updated graphics and better physics are great, Deathmatch: Source doesn't introduce any major changes to the original formula. It feels more like a polished port rather than a revolutionary step forward for the genre. Players expecting something drastically new may be disappointed.

âŒ Lack of Meaningful Progression
Like many classic deathmatch games, thereâ€™s a lack of meaningful progression or any form of unlockable content. While this keeps the focus on pure skill-based play, some players may miss the more modern systems that reward long-term engagement.

Conclusion
Half-Life: Deathmatch: Source is a solid multiplayer shooter for fans of the classic Half-Life experience. Its updated visuals and iconic weapons deliver the fun, high-speed action that fans love, but its small player base and lack of major innovation hold it back from achieving greater popularity. If youâ€™re looking for nostalgic deathmatch action or enjoy modding, itâ€™s a great choice, but donâ€™t expect a revolutionary experience.

Genres: Action, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Strategy, Free To Play
Reviews:
An extremely deep immersive Universe that requires hundreds of hours of guides and youtube videos to learn. On top of that training your character takes Real time not in game time so you can't get good by putting in a lot of hours, unless you spend a lot of money. That being said it's a very rewarding game at times.

Very PVP based because you can be killed everywhere. Learning how to survive more often is a skill in itself. It's hard to trust anyone in this game so if you find people to play with and build with (which i recommend), don't trust them too much. 
BEWARE! The fact everyone is behind a screen truly brings out the worst out in people, and the people in this game take their second life in EVE very very seriously. No lie some of the most toxic people i have EVER seen! This is offset by some people that give the absolute BEST help and introduction, but you're lucky to come across someone like that. 
One time i listed my 330 million ship as 33 million accidentally (which was a huge sum for a beginner like me) and after i messaged the guy he was extremely friendly and sent me the rest of the money.

I'm pretty sure it's only played by adults because of the time and money required to get to the mid-game. 
Regarding CCP games the developer, don't expect them to care, they have been trying to move away from EVE for the past 15 years, they're absolutely sick and tired of working on it, but all their other projects fail miserably.
Don't fly what you can't afford to lose, and if you can buy some starting funds or get them from a helping person. Not having to worry about losing some ships early on while you learn can make ALL the difference in your experience in this game. I would advise to not immediately try and get into Industry or Marketplace because it's one of the hardest things to get into because of the competition you have from well established manufacturers and traders.
Multiboxing is allowed and very much encouraged. EVE is pay to win all the way to the top :)

Bottom line: If you are unemployed, have disposable income, and are a sociopath (i'm joking, please stay away, we already have enough of them), this is the game for you! | multiboxing and micro transacations, as well as high sec being pirated have ruined this game | Here is the response from an elitist in regard to new players being killed and their quest item looted and sold and bricking the new players quest line;

"Sounds like a skill issue to me.

if you watch dscan, local etc. you can easily avoid other people shooting you.

If you run missions in highsec i doubt it that you get permaganked."

So if you're not into this sort of thing, don't know any of what the hell this nerd even means, and are not interested in watching/reading guides just to do quests that are non-pvp to try your best to avoid having your quest line literally bricked then this game is not for you. | The game is an abomination, it's main playerbase is built around finding the newest and inovative way to lie, cheat, screw over, and just plainly try and make your fellow players rage quit. If you're not a part of a guild you will not be able to survive. If you are part of a guild you will still not survive. If you're a new player you will definitely not survive, and you will most definitely be preyed upon continuously until you rage quit.
~This game is not about 3d spaceships going pew pew in space, its a Sociopath/Psychopath Simulator. If you're playing it for the video game and not to enhance your evil side, you're playing it wrong.
~This game is also about spreadsheets and looking at spaceships shoot at rocks for hours on end.
[i]~Legend has it Donald Trump was created in this game [/i] | My playtime ... 600 or so hours ... that's how long it takes to come to the realization that you're better off without this game. I think I'm going to return to Elite Dangerous actually, since you can flag on / off in that game and it is less a spreadsheet simulator and more a space flight simulator.

Eve has gone F2P, but has not bothered to enact the basic PvP flagging system that all other MMO games have. The kind which might attract new players, and retain players who are just sick of the nonsense. You know, adults with real lives who want to casually enjoy a game from time to time. The actual large market you'd think a company would seek out ... 

Do you enjoy feeding the trolls? If yes, play this game. Do you enjoy running from trolls? If yes, play this game. Are you a troll yourself? Then play this game, spend real life money to buy the skills and ships necessary to hunt and kill others, and enjoy.  Eve online turns one person's real life dollars into another person's frustration. It's a direct 1 to 1 relationship - the more real life dollars you spend, the more frustration you can inflict upon other people, and the more insulated you are yourself from the frustration others might inflict on you. Does that get you off? Then you've found your utopia. Link your credit card, and begin trolling other players. This developer has created a shadenfreude machine. It just costs a little bit of money. 

If you want a game to play, where you are able to enjoy playing - by engaging with the PvE elements and NPC's and missions and stories - and opt into PvP sometimes - this is not your game. 

This is 100% a PvP game, all the time and everywhere, and by installing, you are simply a target for the people who have been playing for years.

An incredibly atmospheric world with charismatic and quirky characters. The gameplay can be a bit repetitive and simplistic, but not enough to be to the detrement of the expirience. 

Several fixes are needed to run the original version of the game. The remaster mitigates this issue, though it would seem that it messes with the original art derection through modern rendering tecniques. | It's a great game, but there are a few bugs that never got fixed. One in particular, the game will crash for no reason at any time, so remember to Save Early and Save Often!!! There is also another bug where the game isn't able to locate Double H, the NPC you are adventuring with. This is a game breaking error, and if you get it, you won't be able to continue and will have to either restore to a previous save, or start over which sucks. They haven't fixed the bug in this version, or the newly released 25 anniversary edition. It's still a great game, however, if you can look past these bugs. | i wonder why, since i own this version of the game, there isn't a discount for an upgrade to the improved version of the game? this version that i purchased not that long ago won't even load anymore. instead, seems the publisher wants/expects me to pay again - at full price - for the upgrade. f that! | -Ğ³ĞµĞ¹Ğ¼Ğ´Ğ¸Ğ·Ğ°Ğ¹Ğ½. [b]Inimigos e Combates[/b]

I played this game some years ago and enjoyed it, it's a decent game with some annoying little things, but I remember I liked it anyway and I can totally recommend it. The stealth itself is not "perfect" and when the enemies are searching for you, they will look at you through walls, which can kill your immersion.

Was blown away by how easy it still was to pickup and play. The graphics still hold up fairly well today thanks to the gritty horror artstyle. Sad to see this game was abandoned and that the player base is nearly dead. Still recommend buying it on a good sale to play with friends or try out the singleplayer. Killing Floor is up there with the classic zombie games like CoD and L4D! | As soon as I discovered that characters in this game speak in br*tish accent I downloaded Hatsune Miku character mod. Now I don't even understand a single word she says, but it's definetely better than br*tish accent. | this is what the UK looks like in 2025

also the music in this game is a lot better than it is in the second, much more industrial and gritty, plus no shitty korn-ripoff vocals talking about abortion and god. the audio design in general is just better imo... guns sound amazing. even the 9mm has a punchy and satisfying sound that never gets old, say what you want about tripwire but they know how to make guns sound, look, and FEEL great, red orchestra 2 is a great example of that. 

also, this game is not afraid to punish you with some hefty recoil, which is really nice and adds a solid challenge. i wouldn't call the gunplay "realistic" but it is close enough that it feels pretty damn good. the devs managed to make you feel weak at times, but also strong and badass as hell at other points. shooting the patriarch's limbs off with dual handcannons never gets old.

Gotta love the fact that instead of fixing this mod, Tripwire chose to de list it after it was rolling in dust for 10+ years in a broken state. The only thing I really liked from the newer Civs is the better AI, district planning, hex tiles, and city states. This game also had the vassalage and capitulation options like where the hell did that go in the newer ones that is one of my favorite features in this game. The graphics in this game are kinda aged but at least it doesn't feel like an 8 bit game and is good enough for 2025.

A Solid 9/10 and absolute classic. Have loved it since it first came out and now later in life. I just wish one issue technically/strategically/in terms of game design was fixed. If this was fixed the game would be perfect 10/10. 

As you build up your army organically against the King its population value can sometimes too drastically lower Rebel Sentiment to initiate the Revolution. So you could have towns that are in the high 90% of being pro Independence and being ready to go yet the Overall Score is stuck in the low 30%. This is completely lopsided and after I did everything right with the right buildings, founding fathers etc. 

In essence it's too much of a trade-off between growing your population/army along with maintaining the popularity needed to initiate the revolution. This SHOULD NOT BE A TRADE OFF! This catch 22 problem means you can't win the game as reasonably due to Strategy/Design Error. The best way to fix this is to remove Military Units from the calculation of Rebel Sentiment entirely. 

I have made comments on this issue in forms, on STEAM, along with others. Yet it doesn't seem to be fixed anytime soon. Sad given such a great game.

While this game has great nostagia and is super fun, the controls are so bad that I can<t in good conscience tell modern gamers to buy it. | Crash-tastic! 

My memory of this game, of playing it off a CD, is that you could read an entire comic book waiting for a new level to load. Unfortunately that's the part of the game that has been preserved here. Bugs galore, including having actions edge off screen and characters 'dropping' through buildings making them unmovable or un-engagable. What was fun about this game originally was the campy concept and bright colors. It doesn't look right now. The bright colors and comic book dashes and dots with this early animation style doesn't scream page-turning immersive world. It's like a cheap, superficial game you'd get on a cellphone. 

The missions can be painfully simplistic and there isn't a sense of team building or world building. Your reward is largely your own imagination as you earn enough to unlock 'sets' of abilities or skills. If you're someone who wants the nostalgia either from the original release or from the really, really old comics, this might scratch the itch. If you have even slightly high standards informed by modern games, you'll be disappointed. 

The idea that something this simplistic came out in the same era as the Halo games or even the early Civilization games is a little shocking to contemplate. The people who designed it loved Patriot City and some of the 1980's kind of super villain tropes. They had fun with this, clearly, I just don't think it aged well and given the depth of both missions and conceptual design of other early 2000's games I remain shocked it was ever reviewed and ranked so highly. 

I guess get it if it's on sale or you're really, really curious about what people did when they weren't playing Quake back in the day.

Game Name: The Elder Scrolls IV: OblivionÂ® Game of the Year Edition
Reviews:
If you're new to this title:
Oblivion isn't a game that you play. Oblivion is a game that you conquer.
Yes, the graphics and mechanics haven't aged well. Yes, the dialogue is often hilariously unhinged. And yes, the game is ripe with bugs and quest breaking sequences that induce a paranoid amount of saving. But its' defects can also be broken in your favor. THAT realization is when the game grips you:
What can you get away with? What cheese tactics, what exploits, or what innocuous and obscure thing (like picking up and dropping a paintbrush from your inventory... this is not a joke) can you leverage to your adventureâ€” and how far can you leverage it? And there's so much to be adventured: every nook and cranny or every dungeon, achieve and ace every quest, grind every attribute and skill to max, collect every unique item, and then, after a 100+ hours... lament that it's over.

Which brings us to those who are returning to this title:
You know as well as I that this game has near to no replay value. Everything Oblivion has to offer can be experienced in a single playthrough, and the narrative has little to no variation (nor any substantial dialogue or narrative choices for those hopping for more RP in their RPG like the CRPGs that predated it).

It can be a hell of a ride, but with a story you can only fully revel in once, as a fresh player.
Otherwise you're only left to recall the insatiable desire to see and do everything until the memory of your previous experience is restored, which quickly dulls the experience.
However, on a personal note, I will add: that one thing I recalled was that this was one of the few games that truly made me feel as though I were fighting an endless army of demons; running, jumping, and cutting through one Oblivion gate after another...
And I felt it still, even years after its' initial release.
May it make you feel such heartiness as well. | its a nightmare to make this game stable. but its SUPER modable so you can alter it in any way you want like a sandbox. i recommend your learn the modding tools they are easy and you can make a lot of fun stuff for roleplay etc. and despite the goofiness it can be an engaging story, deep lore and great questlines.

It is a sandbox environment that starts you out on the island that the main city is in, in the center of the map. Each city has a different architectural theme, and a house that you can purchase if you have enough gold and meet the other criteria. The interface is far better than both its predecessor, Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind, and its successor, Elder Scrolls IV: Skyrim. The character design is also superior to both, as they did away with character classes in Skyrim. The game world is more beautiful if you don't follow the main quest past delivering the item to the monk at the piory, because if you close the first oblivion gate then oblivion gates start popping up all over the map. There is plenty to explore without the main quest. | I should have played this ages ago. Much to my regret.

The dev is out of business, all the servers are down, and the game is soon to be crippled by the imminent shutdown of GFWL.

Stay away! | This review was written on January 23, 2011.

The single player is a 3 hour long generic campain, and the multiplayer is long dead and there is no one to play with. Big waste of money even with a big sale. Some promising ideas but Section 8 ends up being way too generic with a dead multiplayer. 

NOT recommended.

PROS

- Dropping from the skies instead of respawning is cool
- Somewhat good cinematics
- All things considered, multiplayer is good and has its own flavor.

CONS

- Campaign is 3-4 hours short, story is shallow, the whole single player aspect is unsatisfying.
- Below average level design. It feels too big most of the time, and even if the scenary looks good (the sky above and the smoke on the horizon), things that are immediately close to you like guns, armors, buildings, and such are generic.
- DEAD multiplayer. As I write this, there are exactly 5 multiplayer servers online, 4 of which are empty. 
- Contrary to the cinematics, the art ingame is mostly bland.

REVIEW

There is not much to say about Section 8. 

The campaign is short and shallow, only 3-4 hours long. When I beat up a mission and seen the credits roll, I was amazed as I thought i was barely 1/4th of the way and just finishing the introduction phase waiting for a greater, more interesting plot to surface. Very disapointed on that aspect. 

If the multiplayer was still alive, I'd give this game a 7 instead of a 5. It has a single mode that is similar to domination (control areas), but it has a nice innovation that is the dynamic objectives. Escorting convoys, fetching intel, or either protection or killing VIPs at random keeps things interesting. But unfortunately it has been a while since the multiplayer fell from the skies and cracked its skull on the hard, cold concrete. Playing with 32 people is fun, but right now there is barely a handful of servers online, most of them empty, and the ones populated have barely a few players on and mostly bots.

CONCLUSION

Because of the dead multiplayer, right now there is no reason to buy this game anymore... unless you find it for 5$ or so, and even then it would still be a questionable purchase.

The jet pack mechanic is not quite as good as Tribes but apart from that it does actually feel like a Tribes 3. The battles also feel very â€œBattlefieldâ€-like which definitely goes in its favour.

Particularly love the 'burn-in' mechanic which always manages to make a respawn feel awesome. The sub-mission mechanic also really livens up the traditional area control maps.  The building mechanic also works well. Certainly enough innovative ideas here to make this a must have. 

Only downsides are that unfortunately the community is quite small with only a few servers. Canâ€™t really blame this on the game though, it deserves a lot attention than it gets. The vehicles could be more interesting too, but they are functional enough. Furthermore inventory management certainly could learn a lot from Tribes

This game is brilliant at allowing you pull of cinematic manoeuvres that leave you feeling awesome.

Game Name: AaAaAA!!! - A Reckless Disregard for Gravity
Reviews: In a world where the simple act of opening a web browser is enough to incite depression, a game that jams itself to the top of your list by screaming, right in the title, is actually incredibly cathartic! What follows next is an entertaining game involving epic BASE jumping to awesome music where the challenge is entirely based on how risky or dramatic the player feels today. Whether you play for 10 minutes or 10 hours, you will come out realizing that, no matter how difficult your day/life/world may be, at least you didn't break all two of your legs. | a simple game to enjoy but you still have to try. i guess this inspired neon white i guess.

Ğ ĞµĞºĞ¾Ğ¼ĞµĞ½Ğ´ÑƒÑ Ğ¸Ğ³Ñ€Ñƒ Ğ´Ğ»Ñ Ğ»ÑĞ±Ğ¸Ñ‚ĞµĞ»ĞµĞ¹ ĞºĞ»Ğ°ÑÑĞ¸Ñ‡ĞµÑĞºĞ¾Ğ¹ Ğ³Ğ¾Ñ‚Ğ¸ĞºĞ¸. | steam keeps asking if i recommend this game and frankly, iâ€™m not sure. i had genuine fun with it for about 50 hours, but i kind of suffered through the last 10. why? because at its core, itâ€™s a solid Piranha Bytes game meaning the hardcore beginning and the lengthy first act (easily half the game) are the best parts. you know, all that classic routine: learning the worldâ€™s rules, figuring out who the baddest baddie is, and choosing a faction to side with. running errands for some sketchy hombres. exploring caves and shores, only to get smashed on the head by a random ostrich (or whatever the hell those things are). getting bullied by the bullies at first and bullying them later. mugging and getting mugged. waking up NPCs in the middle of the night just to pester them with dumb questions. waiting until nightfall just to use the smithy because, during the day, those bulky blacksmith bastards hog it nonstop, leaving you waiting for a turn that will never come. sound familiar? thatâ€™s because this game is basically [i]Gothic[/i], just in a slightly different setting with much better graphics. plus, Kai Rosenkranz composed the ambient music for this one too, and his tunes really hit close to home.

BUT, the first time you try to take on some lizardmen, youâ€™ll realize the combat is janky as hell. all those action points you invested in sword fighting? they donâ€™t mean dreck because those bastards block [i]everything[/i]. every fight becomes a battle of wills: me vs. the will to keep enduring this suffering. and then, when youâ€™ve finished all the open world stuff and only the plot missions remain, youâ€™ll remember: the main story is the weakest part of the game. itâ€™s just uninteresting and painfully boring. again. yep guys, this is truly a Piranha Bytes game. also, i was surprised to see in the credits that Andy Serkis, Lena Headey and Johnathan Rhys-Davies contributed voice work. why? because the acting [i]felt[/i] kind of uninspired. or maybe the writing was so generic and dull that i ended up skipping most of the dialogue and missed everything. who knows?

to wrap this up: after all i do recommend playing this game because Piranha Bytes knows how to create an engaging, tightly packed open world. but beware, itâ€™s an old game, and it has its fair share of jank. actually, quite a lot of jank. but hey, letâ€™s admit it, thatâ€™s part of its charm. | Ğ˜Ğ³Ñ€Ğ° Ğ¿Ñ€Ğ¾ÑÑ‚Ğ¾ Ñ€Ğ°Ğ·Ñ€Ñ‹Ğ² Ğ¾Ñ‡ĞºĞ°! Terrible remaster that adds few QoL fixes and nothing else.

Pros:

- You automatically collect the ammo
- There's an in-game map
- You can use modern resolutions

Cons: 

- No bugs were fixed:  Enemies still fall through the map, pathfinding 100 % broken for AI etc.
- New bugs added: Moxxi Underdome music disappears whenever it feels like it, never addressed. 
- You STILL need to edit .ini file to remove mouse acceleration. Some QoL changes that are possible to change from. ini, crash the game
- There's a memory leak that was never fixed, no matter how much community tried to raise the issue
- Randy Pitchford is still in charge
- Borderlands 4, despite all the half-assed stuff in the remaster is advertised in the main menu like a mobile game pop-up and is the only thing that 100 % works in this case.
